Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Phylogeny and Biogeography of Hyaenodontidae (Mammalia, Placentalia)
Award.AbstractNarration:
In modern ecosystems, the mammals at the top of the food chain are members of the order Carnivora, such as dogs, cats, and hyaenas. But for the much of the Age of Mammals, carnivorans shared the meat-eating niche with an extinct family of mammals called Hyaenodontidae. Species from this diverse family could be found across Eurasia, North America, and Africa. In Africa, these mammals were the primary predators in the ecosystems where our early ancestors evolved. Despite their carnivorous habits, hyaenodontids might not have been closely related to carnivorans, and their place in the mammalian family tree has not yet been established. This research project will clarify the relationships between hyaenodontid species and test the family?s position within the mammalian family tree using molecular and anatomical evidence and sophisticated techniques for reconstructing relationships between species.

A better understanding of the earliest land-based carnivores is essential for understanding the evolution of modern mammalian ecosystems, the evolution of meat-dependent diets, and the biological connections between Eurasian, African, and American ecosystems through the early Cenozoic Era (65 to 10 million years ago). This research has already generated collaborations with high school students, undergraduate students, and has formed part of a course offered to Women in Science and Engineering at Stony Brook University. It has also generated online resources for late elementary and high school teachers who want to use paleontology to teach New York core-curriculum objectives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carnivores serve a vital role in their ecosystems. Their presence and diversity encourages the diversity of prey animals and plant communities. Biologists need to understand the interplay between carnivores and their ecosystems to create targeted conservations goals that support carnivores and, in turn, support the rest of the carnivore’s ecosystem.

 

Today, the apex carnivorous mammals on land – animals like lions, hyenas, and bears – all belong to the order Carnivora, a group of mammals that share traits in their skulls, teeth, skeletons, and genes that tell biologists they all shared a common ancestor. But species from Carnivora have not always been the top carnivores in their ecosystems. In fact, for most of the period after the extinction of the dinosaurs, carnivorans were relatively small. Instead, for 45 million years, the top meat-eating niches in North America, Asia, Europe, and Africa belonged to a mysterious group of mammals from the order Hyaenodontida.

 

Despite the name, these meat eating mammals were not closely related to hyenas, or to lions, wolves, or bears and the evidence comes from their fossils. Carnivorans all have one pair of specialized, scissor-like teeth that let them slice through meat. Hyaenodontidans had three pairs of meat-slicing teeth. They also had long snouts, and large attachment areas on their skulls for strong jaw muscles, and their skeletons were more heavily built than carnivorans (think more bulldog than wolf). They ranged in size from small weasel-like animals to gigantic rhino-sized carnivores that may have preyed on elephants.

 

Their fossils are found across four continents and many dozens of species have been named by paleontologists, but until this research project, few efforts had been made to figure out how hyaenodontidans were related to one another. This information is important for figuring out where they first came from, how they spread out across the planet, and how they shaped their ecosystems before they went extinct 15 million years ago, ceding the floor to the ancestors of modern meat-eaters.

 

In this project I collected the largest database of hyaenodontidan fossils ever examined. I studied and photographed thousands of fossils at sixteen museums in nine different countries, translating the fossils into a list of traits that can be used to figure out how hyaenodontidans are related to each other. I used super computer-assisted algorithms to figure out the most likely set of relationships for hyaenodontidans, including newly developed methods that use information on the ages of fossils to predict when different lineages first evolved and how quickly that happened. These complicated relationships are best visualized in a family tree. Based on the most likely family trees for hyaenodontidans, I was able to figure out where the group first evolved and where different families spread to during the Age of Mammals. Most researchers thought the group originally hailed from Africa, but I demonstrated the evidence actually points to an origin of Hyaenodontida in Europe or Asia. They quickly spread to Africa, North America, and Asia. This radiation around the world closely parallels the history of primates as our earliest primate ancestors made their way out of Asia to North America, Europe, and Africa. With this project, we have evidence that multiple groups of mammals were following the same pathways between these four continents, even though the continents were widely separated at the time. Using my tree of relationships, I was also able to demonstrate that very specialized meat-eating evolved in three different lineages of hyaenodontidans on at least two different continents.
